events.name: espnW Hack Day 2012
events.about:
This fall, ESPN will host its first public Hack event under the espnW brand in partnership with Stanford University. The espnW Hack Day event will bring women in technology — who also love sports -- together to collaborate on mobile, digital and social products for sports fans and athletes.

There will be prizes for the best applications for serving sports fans, as well as for best usage of partner APIs.

Free admission: Coffee, Lunch, Dinner + hack snacks included.

All Experience Levels Welcome.

Brought to you by ESPN, Facebook, Twitter, YouTube, Twilio & Mashery

Tweet about it using #hackespnW

 

Schedule Details

Friday November 9, 2012

  • 5:00PM Registration / Appetizers & Beverages
  • 6:00pm Welcome Address
  • 6:15pm API Demos from ESPN, Facebook, Twitter, YouTube, Twilio, Mashery
  • 7:00pm Idea Pitches
  • 7:45pm Team Formation + Networking
  • 9:00pm Doors Close

Saturday November 10, 2012

  • 8:00 - 9:00am Registration / Breakfast
  • 9:00 - 10:00am Intro / API Demos
  • 10:00am – 6:00pm Hacking! Coding! Designing!
  • 12:30 - 1:30pm Lunch
  • 1:30 - 5:30pm Mad Afternoon Rush to finish hack
  • 1:30 - 5:30pm Mad rush to finish hack
  • 6:00pm Submission Deadline
  • 6:00 - 6:30pm Dinner
  • 6:30 - 7:45pm Presentations
  • 7:45 - 8:15pm Judging
  • 8:15 - 8:45pm Awards
  • 9:00pm Doors Close 

Prizes 

  • Best Use of Twilio API: Nike Fuel Bands and $50 Twilio credit for each member winning team (Maximum: 4 team members)
  • Best Use of Facebook API $750 in Facebook Ads credits and a Facebook sweatshirt for each team member
  • Best Use of Twitter API Twitter Schwag Bags (Maximum: 4 team members)
  • Best Use of YouTube API Nexus 7 Tablet
  • Best Demo of Mashery API Network: BIG JAMBOX by Jawbone
  • More prizes coming soon!
 

Judges

Confirmed judges include:

  • Rob King (SVP Editorial, ESPN Digital and Print Media)
  • Danielle Tiedt (Chief Marketing Officer, YouTube)
  • Sara Haider (Sr. Software Engineer, Twitter for Android)
  • Sophia Chung (Software Engineer, Facebook)
  • Jessica Kahn (VP, Product, Engineering, and Operations, Disney Mobile)

Additional judges and speakers will be announced soon.

 

Directions and Parking

From Highway 101 North & South or El Camino Real

Take the Embarcadero Road exit west toward Stanford. At El Camino Real, Embarcadero becomes Galvez Street as it enters the university. Stay in the left lane on Galvez and at the stop sign turn left onto Campus Drive. Continue on Campus Drive until you reach Mayfield Ave (about 1 mile). Turn right onto Mayfield Ave. After a forced left turn there is a large parking lot off of Mayfield on the right side. (Parking is $1.50 per hour from 8 a.m. to 4:30 p.m. and credit cards, bills and coins are accepted.) If you park as far from Mayfield Ave. as you can, you will be in closer proximity to our building. Once parked, walk north towards Tresidder Union which can be recognized by its outdoor tables. Walk with the Tresidder Union on your left side and you will see the Old Union directly in front of you. Take a left to walk between Tresidder Union and Old Union, and then a right onto Duena Street, keeping Old Union on your right. At the next intersection with Panama Mall, make a left onto Panama. The d.school is two buildings down. On several doors, you’ll see “Thomas F. Peterson Engineering Laboratory.” You’ve arrived!

From Highway 280 North & South

Exit at Alpine Road. Take Alpine Road east toward Palo Alto. Turn right at the first light onto Junipero Serra Blvd. Turn left at the first light onto Campus Drive West. Take the second right onto Santa Teresa St. After two blocks, take a right onto Lomita Rd. Drive one block and turn left onto Mayfield Ave. There is a large parking lot off of Mayfield on the left side. (Parking is $1.50 per hour from 8 a.m. to 4:30 p.m. and credit cards, bills and coins are accepted.) If you park as far from Mayfield Ave. as you can, you will be in closer proximity to our building. Once parked, walk north towards Tresidder Union which can be recognized by its outdoor tables. Walk with the Tresidder Union on your left side and you will see the Old Union directly in front of you. Take a left to walk between Tresidder Union and Old Union, and then a right onto Duena Street, keeping Old Union on your right. At the next intersection, Panama Mall, make a left onto Panama. The d.school is two buildings down. On several doors, you’ll see “Thomas F. Peterson Engineering Laboratory.”

Additional parking and directions information can be found on the Stanford d.school site.

 

Brought to you by
events.address: (Thomas F. Peterson Engineering Laboratory/Building 550) 550 Panama Mall

events.name: Hack the Future 4
events.about:
Are you a 5th-12th grade student who wants to learn more about computers than they teach you in school? Then its time to start teaching yourself! 

Hack the Future is an all-day party / hackathon for youth, to show you how to teach yourself how to be a hacker. Its run by volunteers who work in technology in the area. Youll see what its like to be a hacker and see if its for you. We dont tell you what to do. Youre be free to work on whatever you want. We give you a place to start if you need it, and we get you unstuck when you need it.. This is a unique opportunity to learn the the state of the art in software engineering from the people who do it for a living. Parents, dont reserve a ticket for yourself. Once youve signed the waiver, we encourage you to let your children learn on their own! If you want to stay and join in, youre welcome, but we wont have a T-shirt for you.

Bring a laptop for programming and signed waiver and medical information sheet (even if you brought a waiver before). The waiver and required medical information sheet are available on hackthefuture.org.

Suggested donation: $10

To learn more or sign up for our mailing lists, find out about more Hack the Future events, or see pictures from the first Hack the Future, visit http://www.hackthefuture.org. You can also visit our Facebook page here

events.name: Puppet Labs Hackathon at Stanford University for Stanford Students and Faculty
events.about:
Puppet Labs (http://www.puppetlabs.com) and Stanford IT Services is hosting this event on Stanford campus Redwood Hall G19 for Stanford students and faculty, all others please contact the host. This single day workshop will focus on solving interesting configuration management problems with Puppet.  Puppet labs will provide an overview on puppet, modules development, rspec-puppet unit testing, and travis.ci integration testing. They can also provide assistance with projects related to native types, providers, bugs fix, and custom facts or functions. If there is interest and time, there could be lightning talks at the end.

Bring your laptop! There is limited power available in the room, so please bring a power strip with a long cord if you have one available.

Parking is permitted or paid only.  There is hourly/daily parking available in Parking Structure 5, or occasionally in Parking Structure 2.

Some special event permits that are valid for only the roof of Parking Structure 5 are available. Attendees who wish to use them will need to pick one up prior to driving to the roof of Parking Structure 5 and scratching the day+month+year off of the permit.  Failure to have a parking permit or pay the hourly/daily parking will result in a parking ticket.

Puppet Labs Attendee:
Dan Bode & Nan Liu

Location:
Stanford Redwood Hall G19:
http://campus-map.stanford.edu/?id=&lat=37.43094933363171&lng=-122.17969394207233&zoom=17&srch=redwood_hall
